byline.contributor: Sarah Li contributed research from Guangzhou, and Adam Wu and Mia Li from Beijing.

abstract: China's lucrative manta ray gill trade, for which vendors claim medicinal properties, has come under fire from wildlife conservationists who argue dubious remedy endangers not just manta ray population but consumers given toxic substances found in gills; campaign to end sale of manta ray gills has found both grassroots support and government backing.
lead_paragraph: Demand for the gills, which researchers say were never used in traditional medicine and may actually do harm, has led to overfishing and spurred a conservation campaign.

headline.main: China Weighs Ban on Manta Ray Gills, Sold in Traditional Market as Modern Panacea
headline.print_headline: A Conservation Drive Gains Ground in China

snippet: Demand for the gills, which researchers say were never used in traditional medicine and may actually do harm, has led to overfishing and spurred a conservation campaign.
